title: LUCAS - Land Use and Carbon Scenario Simulator
summary: The Land Use and Carbon Scenario Simulator (LUCAS) tracks changes in land use, land cover, land management, and disturbance, and their impacts on ecosystem carbon storage and flux. LUCAS is a state-and-transition simulation model designed to track changes in land use, land cover, land management, and disturbance, and their impacts on ecosystem carbon storage and flux. See 'Overview': https://www.usgs.gov/centers/wgsc/science/lucas-model?qt-science_center_objects=0#qt-science_center_objects Model Name (Name of the model, including acronyms): LUCAS - Land Use and Carbon Scenario Simulator Model Version (Version of the model, (i.e., 2.0)): Abstract (Description or summary of the model, including its purpose or goals and the type or formalism [...]
body:
The Land Use and Carbon Scenario Simulator (LUCAS) tracks changes in land use, land cover, land management, and disturbance, and their impacts on ecosystem carbon storage and flux. LUCAS is a state-and-transition simulation model designed to track changes in land use, land cover, land management, and disturbance, and their impacts on ecosystem carbon storage and flux.

See 'Overview': https://www.usgs.gov/centers/wgsc/science/lucas-model?qt-science_center_objects=0#qt-science_center_objects

Model Name (Name of the model, including acronyms):

LUCAS - Land Use and Carbon Scenario Simulator

Model Version (Version of the model, (i.e., 2.0)):

Abstract (Description or summary of the model, including its purpose or goals and the type or formalism of the model (e.g., system dynamic, agent based model, machine learning), preferably accompanied by relevant keywords):

"The Land Use and Carbon Scenario Simulator (LUCAS) tracks changes in land use, land cover, land management, and disturbance, and their impacts on ecosystem carbon storage and flux."

See 'Overview': https://www.usgs.gov/centers/wgsc/science/lucas-model?qt-science_center_objects=0#qt-science_center_objects

Originator(s) (Name(s) of the model developer(s)/author(s)):

Benjamin M Sleeter (bsleeter@usgs.gov)

U.S. Geological Survey

Mission Area (USGS mission area with which this model most clearly aligns. https://www.usgs.gov/science/mission-areas):

Ecosystems

Resources (Resources (how to use the model, where to download it, related publications, other webpages about the model (in other catalogs), USGS webpage):

USGS Webpage: https://www.usgs.gov/centers/wgsc/science/lucas-model?qt-science_center_objects=0#qt-science_center_objects

Image (URL for an image that best represents the model, title of image, alternate text, URL of source):

Model Type (theoretical model, empirical model, or list both):

land use change

Requirements (All software and/or hardware requirements needed to run the model and replicate any published results):

Assumptions (What are the key assumptions made that define the dynamics of the model?):

Structure (Model structure: provide a flow diagram of the model. (e.g. [Growing Degree Days since Jan 1]+[Warm Spells]=[Leaf Out Day of Year] and [Growing Degree Days since Leaf Out Day of Year]+[Warm Spells]=[Bloom Day of Year])):

Equations (What are the equations of the model?):

Temporal Information (Temporal resolution, time stepping, and units):

Spatial Information (Spatial dimensionality, resolution, extent, grid type if relevant):

Limitations (Limitations, domain ranges: What is this model specifically NOT intended to do):

Input/Output and Variables (Key input parameters and their values and domain ranges and units (minimum input requirements for model operation and default values, where appropriate); control variables; Key output variables and domain ranges):

Conditions (Initial conditions):

Functions (Forcing functions that affect the dynamics of the model):

Example (Provide sample runs that illustrate the dynamics of the model):

Evaluation (Model evaluation, uncertainty, and sensitivity):

Benchmarks (Describe or provide benchmarks for validation of your model):

Usage (Measure of use / community support (citations, forks, commits, members)):

Model Components (A subsection of the model that simulates a subset of processes (ex. COAWST)): "The LUCAS model combines:

-State-and-Transition Simulation Model to simulate changes in land-use across a range of geographic scales.

-Stock and Flow Model to track the movement of carbon between different “pools” including interactions between land and atmosphere.

-Linkage to the Integrated Biosphere Simulator (IBIS) dynamic global vegetation model."

See 'Overview/The LUCAS Model': https://www.usgs.gov/centers/wgsc/science/lucas-model?qt-science_center_objects=0#qt-science_center_objects
